text: We analyze the relationship between climate change and crop yields in Africa, using data from the World Bank's Living Standards Measurement Study — Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA) and the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data (CHIRPS).

Using a dataset from the World Trade Organization on bilateral trade flow and applied tariff data for 75 countries over 30 years, we investigate the impact of non-tariff measures (NTMs) on trade flows.

This study examines the impact of school-based management interventions on primary school student learning outcomes, using data from the Philippine Informal Reading Inventory (Phil-IRI) and the National Achievement Test (NAT).

We explore the impact of electricity access on household welfare using data from the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) and the World Bank's Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS), both conducted in Nigeria.

To investigate the relationship between social protection programs and job quality in emerging economies, we use a panel dataset of labor force surveys from seven countries, namely Colombia, Mexico, Peru, Brazil, South Africa, Turkey, and India.
We analyze the effect of remittance on rural households' income and consumption in Nepal using data from the Nepal Living Standards Survey (NLSS) and the National Sample Census of Agriculture (NSCA).

This paper examines the impact of infrastructure development on tourism demand using a panel dataset on 129 developing countries, taken from the World Bank's Infrastructure Database and the United Nations World Tourism Organization.

To investigate the effect of financial sector development on economic growth in Africa, we use a panel dataset that includes indicators such as private sector credit to GDP ratio, stock market capitalization, and interest rate spread from the World Bank's Financial Sector Development Indicators and the International Monetary Fund's African Economic Outlook.

We examine the role of governance and institutions in shaping forest cover change in Indonesia using district-level panel data from the Indonesian Ministry of Forestry and the World Bank Forests database.
This study analyzes the relationship between socio-economic characteristics and health outcomes in Bangladesh using data from two waves of the Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey (BDHS).
This report employs the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys data to examine the relationship between firms' exporting activities and financial constraints in Central Asia.
The study investigates the implementation of public-private partnerships (PPPs) using data from the National Public Private Partnership Unit (N3PU) in Uganda.
Using the Demographic and Health Survey dataset, this paper examines the factors affecting maternal health-seeking behaviors in low-income countries.
In this study, we analyze the effects of trade agreements by utilizing a matched firm-level dataset of Brazilian exporters called Comex Stat.
This research paper constructs a novel dataset from household survey data merged with local climatic information measured at higher spatial resolution for sub-Saharan Africa.
This article uses data on government procurement contracts provided by the Mexican Compranet to investigate the impact of institutional corruption on public contracting outcomes.

We combine satellite observations from the Landsat program with socioeconomic data drawn from the Global Rural-Urban Mapping Project (GRUMP) to assess the impacts of urbanization on agricultural land conversion in India.

This research leverages a unique dataset of mobile phone metadata provided by the Telecommunications Regulatory Authority (TRA) of Bahrain to examine the travel patterns of individuals during religious pilgrimage.

To understand the impact of natural disasters on household welfare, we use data from the Indonesia Family Life Survey (IFLS), combined with district-level climate data derived from the Climate Research Unit at the University of East Anglia.
In this study, we utilize a panel dataset that integrates firm-level data with customs transaction data to explore the effect of non-tariff measures on trade performance in developing countries.

We analyze the relationship between carbon emissions and economic development using the World Development Indicators (WDI) dataset along with complementary datasets on renewable energy use and technology adoption.
This research is based on a unique dataset of 100,000 job postings scraped from various online platforms in India supplemented by data from the Labour Bureau and Census of India.
Our study employs data from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) to investigate the determinants of child malnutrition in low-income countries.
Using panel data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey and Afrobarometer, we analyze the effect of government bureaucracy on private sector development and citizen trust in Africa.

In this paper, we use data from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and Global Power Plant Database (GPPD) to examine the impact of renewable energy policies on investment in solar and wind power plants worldwide.

Through an analysis of satellite imagery and ground-based measurements, our study assesses the impact of drought on crop yield in Ethiopia using data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO).

We use data from the World Bank's Doing Business report and Enterprise Surveys to investigate the relationship between regulatory quality, firm productivity, and export performance in emerging economies.

Our research applies a combination of household survey data from the World Bank's Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) and macroeconomic data from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to analyze the impact of inflation on income distribution in Southeast Asia.
Using cross-country data compiled by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Bank, we examine the relationship between healthcare expenditure and health outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa.

Our study employs a combination of administrative data from the Social Security Administration (SSA) and the American Community Survey (ACS) to evaluate the effectiveness of job training programs for low-income workers in the United States.

We investigate the impact of social safety net programs on poverty reduction using micro-level household survey data from the World Bank's Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) and administrative data on program beneficiaries.
We analyze data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and the PISA surveys to study the determinants of innovation in developing countries.
Using data from the 2012 National Survey of Children's Health (NSCH), we investigate the relationship between adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) and health in early childhood.
This study is based on data obtained from the China Family Panel Studies (CFPS) 2010 and 2018 waves, which provide information on household income, consumption, and assets over time.
We draw on data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health) to assess the degree to which adolescents' social status affects their subsequent health outcomes.
Using a dataset consisting of tweets gathered during the initial stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in Europe, we examine whether social media can be used as a reliable indicator of disease activity.
We use a comprehensive dataset covering nearly all retail banks in Mexico to analyze the effects of competition on bank performance.

To quantify the economic benefits of improved transport infrastructure, we use satellite imagery data and GIS analysis to estimate changes in land values associated with the construction of new motorways.
We analyze data from the World Values Survey and the European Values Study to investigate the determinants of trust and social capital in Europe.

This paper presents new data on Chinese Overseas Development Finance (ODF) activities in Africa, collected through a collaborative research project between AidData and the Kiel Institute for the World Economy.
We use two complementary datasets from the Mexican government to assess the impact of minimum wage increases on the labor market.
Using the Global Terrorism Database and the World Development Indicators dataset, we investigate the relationship between terrorist attacks and economic development.

This study utilizes data from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and the Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) to examine the relationship between women's empowerment and child health outcomes in developing countries.

We analyzed data from the Global Burden of Disease as well as climate data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) to estimate the health impacts of heatwaves in different regions of the world.
To assess the impact of trade on employment, we use a panel dataset on manufacturing firms covering several African countries and complement it with household survey data.

Using publicly available financial data and environmental datasets, this study investigates the relationship between corporate sustainability performance and financial performance of companies in emerging economies.

We analyze a unique dataset on child nutrition and education outcomes in rural areas of India, and supplement it with geospatial data on water resources and infrastructure to explore the determinants of nutritional adequacy and educational achievement among children.
This paper uses satellite imagery data and census data to estimate the causal impact of electrification on household welfare and economic development in rural areas of sub-Saharan Africa.

Using household survey data and spatial datasets on land use and forest cover, this study examines the factors driving deforestation and explores the potential for incentive-based mechanisms to reduce forest loss and improve livelihoods of local communities in Cameroon.

We construct a new dataset on cross-country infrastructure connectivity and use it to analyze how transportation infrastructure affects trade flows and economic growth in different regions of the world.

This study utilizes micro-level survey data on households and firms in Ghana and Kenya and complements it with macroeconomic datasets on credit markets and natural resource endowments to investigate the channels through which financial inclusion policies can promote economic growth and poverty reduction in sub-Saharan Africa.

This paper utilizes microdata from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1979 (NLSY79) and its supplements to provide a comprehensive analysis of the long-term effects of early life exposure to air pollution on cognitive development and human capital formation.
We examine this issue using district-level data on electricity consumption obtained from the National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA).
Our analysis is based on comprehensive, panel dataset containing disaggregated data on health center inputs and outputs for all public and private health facilities in Uganda from 2003 to 2010.
We use cross-country data from the OECD Framework for the Assessment of Environment Indicators (OECD) from 2000 to 2016 to perform our analysis on environmental sustainability.

Our study is based on panel data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys (WBES), which is an extensive dataset collected in partnership with various survey organizations covering more than 130 countries over the period 2002-2017.

We use a unique dataset on patent filings by inventors at USPTO and EPO from 1998 to 2010 along with the number of citations received by each of these patents to investigate the relationship between inward FDI and innovation performance.

We use synthetic control methods and a unique dataset of satellite measurements from NASA's Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) to estimate the causal impact of air pollution on public health in India.

We analyze household survey data from multiple rounds of the Ghana Living Standards Survey (GLSS), providing a rich dataset consisting of information on income, assets, consumption and expenditures from 1991 to 2016.

Our study draws on nationally representative individual-level panel data from the German Socio-Economic Panel Study (SOEP) covering the period 1984 to 2017 to analyze the effects of non-cognitive skills on labor market outcomes.

Using household survey data from the Mozambique National Agricultural Sample Survey (NASS), we demonstrate the significant negative impacts of exposure to droughts and floods on agricultural production.

To analyze the impact of economic sanctions on poverty, we utilize panel data from the World Bank's World Development Indicators (WDI) and the United Nations Development Programme's Human Development Index (HDI).

This research examines the gender differences in human capital accumulation in India using a dataset from the National Sample Survey Organisation (NSSO) and the Annual Status of Education Report (ASER) published by Pratham.

In this paper, we investigate the causal relationship between education and health outcomes in Malawi using data from the Malawi Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and the Integrated Household Panel Survey (IHPS).

Using firm-level datasets from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and the Global Financial Inclusion (Global Findex) database provided by the World Bank Group, we examine the determinants and effects of access to finance on firm-level foreign investment decisions in emerging markets.

We assess the impact of urbanization on nutritional status of children in sub-Saharan Africa using household survey data from the Demographic and Health Surveys Program (DHS) and Global Urban Growth Indicators (GUGI) collected by the World Bank.
The study considers the impact of government spending on income disparity in Brazil making use of data from the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) and the World Income Database.

To investigate the impact of climate change on crop yields, we employ district level panel data spanning more than 30 years from the India Meteorological Department (IMD), the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations and World Bank's Agro-Climate Toolkits (ACTs).

Using high-frequency mobile phone data provided by call detail records made available through a partnership between Facebook and Vodafone in six African countries, we examine the relationship between drought and internal migration patterns in sub-Saharan Africa.

We utilize datasets obtained from the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series (IPUMS) for different years of American Community Surveys (ACS) and from Decennial Census to analyze the impact of residential segregation on intergenerational mobility in the United States.

This study explores the relationship between natural disasters and tourism in large cities around the world, drawing on several datasets including DisasterData.org, OpenStreetMap, CityGML, as well as geotagged social media data from Twitter and Instagram.
This study uses a combination of household survey data from the LSMS and administrative data from the Brazilian government to assess the impact of the Bolsa Família program on poverty reduction.
We investigate the relationship between temperature and infant mortality in sub-Saharan African countries using monthly weather data from CHIRPS and demographic data from DHS.

To analyze the effects of foreign aid on political polarization in Africa, we use cross-national data on political coalitions from the Varieties of Democracy (V-Dem) dataset and foreign aid data from AidData.
This paper draws on two datasets: World Bank Enterprise Surveys and trade statistics from COMTRADE to examine the relationship between innovation and firm-level exports in developing economies.

We employ a mediation framework with monthly data on COVID-19 cases and deaths from the Our World in Data repository and data on mobility from Google Community Mobility Reports to explore the role of mobility in COVID-19 transmission.
Using a global panel dataset on forests from Global Forest Watch and geospatial data on land use from Land Use Harmonization 2.1, we estimate the causal effect of deforestation on local temperatures.

This study exploits the spatial variation in rainwater storage from CHIRPS and household survey data from LSMS to examine the effects of rainfall shocks on income diversification strategies of rural households.

To assess the impact of renewable energy subsidies on electricity generation, we assemble a novel dataset by merging regulation data on feed-in tariffs from the Global Atlas for Renewable Energy with production data from the International Energy Agency.

We combine satellite remote sensing data from NASA's Terra and Aqua satellites with surveys on crop yields, pesticide use and profiles of land conditions from USAID's Bureau of Humanitarian Assistance to estimate the impact of climate variability on food security.
This study employs hospital discharge data from the Institute of Health Metrics and Evaluation to investigate the effects of smoking on asthma incidence.

This study uses the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys dataset and a new dataset on political connections to investigate the relationship between firm-level political connections and access to finance in developing countries.
We analyze a large-scale dataset of household survey data from Haiti to estimate the local average treatment effect of education on labor market outcomes using an instrumental variable approach.

This paper exploits the variation provided in two micro datasets: (i) individual level data on prime age men from the National Longitudinal Survey (NLS) of Youth and (ii) aggregated manufacturing industry-level data from the Annual Survey of Manufacturers (ASM)

We analyze a unique dataset of school inspections data and daily teacher attendance records to examine the relationship between school inspections, teacher incentive policies and teacher absenteeism in India.
This analysis uses data from the DHS conducted in multiple countries to explore the association between maternal empowerment and child stunting in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa.
Using a new dataset of over 200,000 public procurement auctions, we document substantial variation in the use of subcontracting across US states and purchasing agencies.
This paper uses a unique dataset of individual-level financial linkages data to investigate the relationship between bank network structure and systemic risk in the banking sector.
We exploit variation in government audit schemes and administrative data on fiscal revenues to identify the causal impacts of fiscal audits on taxpayer behavior in Mexico.

The analysis combines an unprecedented dataset on stock prices for firms listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange together with a comprehensive new dataset on patent applications filed by South African inventors at various patent offices around the world.

Using a unique dataset of agricultural survey data, we provide evidence that shocks to the agriculture industry have spillover effects across the entire community as measured by a decline in social capital.
This analysis draws on data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor to examine the relationship between informal entrepreneurship and firm performance.

We used data from the Demographic and Health Survey along with a matched user survey to clarify the reasons for the low use of maternal health services in Nigeria despite improved supply-side conditions.

This study merges household level survey data from the Tanzania National Panel Survey with data from Tanzania's unified agriculture survey to investigate the determinants of fertilizer adoption among Tanzanian smallholder farmers.
Using panel data from the Bangladesh Economic Census covering a period of over 15 years, we analyze how both spatial and aggregate trends affect industrial diversity patterns.

In this paper, we provide a comprehensive estimate of local temperature responses for crop yields through massive data combination, synthesizing findings from six different empirical strategies that include geographically weighted regression, high-dimensional fixed effect models, A/B testing, difference-in-difference methods, and structural modeling, based on a dataset of global gridded weather and crop yield data.

We assess changes in air quality across India due to the reduction in sulfur emissions from power plants, using satellite-derived aerosol optical depth measurements, ground-based monitoring data, and atmospheric model simulations.

Using cross-sectional data from the China Family Panel Studies, we explore the relationship between parental education and child's health outcomes, taking into account the role of health insurance coverage and maternal mental health status.

This paper combines a firm-level dataset from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys with disaggregated product code trade data to advance our understanding on how services liberalization may affect firms' decisions and economic performance.

We use a novel dataset that links information on internet access usage, telecommunications infrastructure, and firm-level data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys to study the relationship between access to digital technologies and firm performance.

In this paper, we use fine-grained data at the disaggregated product level to identify the mechanisms by which input tariffs affect the productivity of firms using data from French Customs and VAT returns along with confidential customs data at the firm-product level.

Our analysis is based on household survey data from the National Statistics Office (NSO) of the Philippines and the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) Program datasets, which cover various years in this period.
The study uses the World Bank database on fiscal decentralization around the world to create a panel dataset for 103 countries over the period 1993-2014.
Our study combines information from multiple data sources including population-based surveys, administrative records, and medical records.

We use data from the Employer Identification Number (EIN) system in the U.S. Social Security Administration's Business Register and county-level characteristics from the County Business Patterns dataset.

This paper leverages new digitized historical economic data and complementary statistical and legal government records available at the local level to reconstruct Bolivian municipalities' economic history.
We used nationally representative data from the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) program conducted in several West African countries with high rates of child marriage and adolescent fertility.

In our analysis of the relationship between credit growth and real estate prices, we use data from a unique panel dataset on European commercial properties from 2004-2016, as well as complementary macroeconomic data from the World Bank.

Our study uses the World Bank's IDA resource allocation formula to simulate the impact of reallocating resources in different ways, drawing on annual panel data from 2007 to 2019 for all IDA countries.

Using detailed data on expenditures from the Colombian government's Sistema Integrado de Información Financiera (Integrated Financial Information System), this paper estimates cost functions for public schools across different municipalities.

We analyzed data sets from the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) reporting platform and from Bitcointicker.co to observe how changes in global temperature indices affect Bitcoin price movements during two specific periods of historical events, i.e., the Paris climate agreement signing and the COVID-19 pandemic outbreak.

This analysis combines data from the World Bank's Enterprise survey and the Doing Business report to explore the relationship between business formalization and access to credit in low-income economies.

We use a combination of cross-country data from the UN Development Programme, the World Health Organization, and the World Bank to examine the relationship between health outcomes and government expenditure on health.

This paper employs an event study design to analyze the effects of floods across the United States using data on extreme precipitation events from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).

Using a panel dataset of over 1 million firms in developing countries, we examine the impact of competition on firm-level productivity and innovation, as measured by the World Bank's Enterprise survey and the Global Innovation Index.

We use household survey data from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and the Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) to explore the pathways through which maternal education affects child nutrition outcomes in low-income settings.

To identify the effect of natural resource wealth on economic development, we take advantage of a new dataset on resource-rich areas from the Natural Resource Governance Institute (NRGI), which we match with a comprehensive panel dataset of countries from the World Bank.
We use administrative data on tax returns and linked birth records to measure the impact of income and child support policy on family formation and dissolution in the United States.

Using a dataset of women-owned microenterprises in Africa, Asia, and Latin America from the International Labour Organization, we assess the effects of mentorship and training on enterprise growth and sustainability.

This study draws on a large-scale survey of residents in urban and peri-urban areas in three metropolitan cities in India conducted by the Energy Policy Institute to investigate the determinants of household energy consumption and adoption of clean cooking technologies.

We compile a dataset of bilateral migration stocks and flows from 1960 to 2020 for all countries in the world using data from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), and the World Bank.

To examine the relationship between infrastructure investment and regional development outcomes in China, this study uses a dataset compiled by the National Development and Reform Commission based on China's officially planned infrastructure projects in 2005-2014, complemented by data from official statistics and other sources.
We combined three datasets, the World Development Indicators, the African Development Indicators and the Enterprise Survey, to assess the competitiveness of the private sector in Kenya.

Using data from the Demographic and Health Survey (DHS), we found that women with higher education attainment are more likely to use modern contraceptive methods than those with lower education attainment in Nigeria.
This study analyzes the impact of traffic congestion on housing prices in Jakarta, Indonesia using a dataset derived from Google Maps estimated travel time and property listing data from Rumah.com.
We use the World Bank Education Statistics dataset and the PISA dataset to analyze the determinants of education quality across countries.
To examine the relationship between poverty and malnutrition in India, we merged two datasets - the India Human Development Survey and the Comprehensive National Nutrition Survey.
Using a combination of satellite imagery and the Global Forest Watch dataset, we assessed the effectiveness of forest conservation policies in Brazil.
We compared the effectiveness of social protection policies in Ghana, Tanzania and Uganda using the Living Standards Measurement Study - Integrated Surveys on Agriculture dataset.
We used the World Bank Logistics Performance Index dataset to identify the factors that contribute to efficient logistics systems in developing countries.

We analyzed the relationship between economic growth and natural disasters in South Asia using disaster data from the International Disaster Database and economic data from the World Development Indicators dataset.

This study uses three different datasets, the Tanzania National Panel Survey, the ILO Labour Force Survey and the Tanzania Household Health Survey, to examine gender disparities in labour market outcomes and health status in Tanzania.
This report analyzes data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys for the year 2020 to understand how COVID-19 has impacted the business environment in South Asia.
The study uses data from the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) and assesses the effect of infrastructure on employment creation over two decades in India.

We analyzed two waves of survey data from the Philippines Longitudinal Study of Aging (PLSA) to examine the factors affecting the social pension program enrollment and its impact on the well-being of older Filipinos.

We use a novel dataset that merges information on population demographics, schooling outcomes, and poverty indicators with a dataset on cellular network coverage in Madagascar to identify the geographical disparities in access to digital services.

The paper utilizes a combination of satellite remote sensing data obtained from Copernicus Climate Change Service and crop yield data from US Department of Agriculture National Agricultural Statistics Service to analyze the effects of temperature shocks on crop yields in Nebraska.
We collected data from the World Development Indicators on gender disaggregated employment to examine the association between gender equality at work and economic growth across developing countries.

We used two sources of data- the Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS) and Demographic Health Surveys (DHS) to investigate the effect of household air pollution from solid fuels on women's health in Indonesia.
This study compiles a comprehensive dataset that combines CommTrade, African Development Bank, and UNIDO datasets to map the patterns of African exports and assess their structural characteristics.
Using panel data from firms in seven African countries, we examine how corporate social responsibility activities influence the financial performance of firms using regression analysis.

We use a mix of satellite imagery, government statistics and household surveys to identify vulnerable populations and estimate losses associated with Damaging Hydro-Meteorological Phenomenon (DHMPs) in Papua New Guinea over the period 2010-2020.

This research analyzes the relationship between child nutrition indicators and agricultural productivity in Ethiopia, drawing on data from both the Ethiopia Socioeconomic Survey and the Ethiopian Rural Household Survey.
We explore the determinants of air pollution levels across Chinese cities using two datasets: the China City Statistical Yearbook and the National Bureau of Statistics Urban Household Survey.

This article investigates how social protection policies can reduce income inequality, utilizing data from both the World Income Inequality Database and the Demographic and Health Surveys within a panel dataset framework.

We evaluate infrastructure projects in three African countries using a comprehensive dataset comprising loan-level data from the China Development Bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, and the Export-Import Bank of China.

This paper examines the economic effects of climate change in Bangladesh by analyzing data from both the Household Income and Expenditure Survey and the Bangladesh Climate Change Knowledge Management Center's database on natural disasters.
We investigate the relationship between financial inclusion and gender inequality using data from both the World Bank's Global Findex database and the Gender Data Portal.

This study analyzes the impact of extractive industries on local communities in Latin America using data from both the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and the Living Standards Measurement Survey.

We assess the impact of expanding regional integration through cross-border investment using data from both the World Investment Report and the Economic Community of West African States Trade Liberalization Scheme.
To estimate the impacts of digital development on economic growth, we use data from both the World Development Indicators and the Global Information Technology Report.

This paper examines the relationship between governance and disaster risk management by analyzing data from both the Worldwide Governance Indicators and the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction.
This analysis is based on data from the World Health Organization's Global Health Observatory and the United Nations Statistics Division.
We used data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health to examine the relationship between family structure and adolescent health outcomes.
This report combines survey data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and financial statement data from Orbis.
To understand the drivers of deforestation in Brazil, we combined spatially explicit data from the Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation (EMBRAPA) and field-based surveys.
Using data from the International Labor Organization's Labor Force Survey, we analyzed trends in informal employment across several countries in Southeast Asia.

We complemented household survey data from the Living Standards Measurement Study and demographic data from the United Nations Population Division with climate data from the Climatic Research Unit at the University of East Anglia.
This study uses data from the World Values Survey and the European Social Survey to investigate the relationship between income inequality and social trust.
We used data from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth to examine the effect of early childhood education on later life outcomes.

This analysis uses a combination of satellite imagery from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's VIIRS instrument and census data from the Government of India to study the impact of electrification on light pollution in rural areas.

To understand the drivers of economic growth in Africa, we combined data on infrastructure stocks from the World Bank's Infrastructure Capital Stock Database with data on public expenditure from the International Monetary Fund's Government Finance Statistics database.

This study utilizes the World Development Indicators dataset and additional surveys on entrepreneurship to examine the relationship between access to finance and small business growth in low-income countries.

We analyze data from the April 2019 round of the High-Frequency Phone Survey on Tobacco conducted by the National Bureau of Statistics, Nigeria to investigate the impact of tobacco taxes on smoking prevalence in Nigeria.
Using firm-level data from the Enterprise Surveys conducted by the World Bank Group, we explore the determinants of corporate social responsibility activities in Southeast Asia.

This paper combines household consumption survey data with satellite imagery data from the European Space Agency's Sentinel missions to explore the relationship between urbanization and food security in sub-Saharan Africa.

With the purpose of exploring the relationship between air pollution and labor market outcomes, we gather data from the Demographic and Health Surveys and combine it with satellite-derived data on exposure to fine particulate matter.

Using data from the National Census and Housing Survey and the National Survey of Urban Public Transport, we analyze the effects of public transport investment on urban development and migration patterns in Brazil.

In order to investigate the effect of gender diversity on firm performance, we combine panel data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys with information on national gender policies and cultural values from Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions dataset.
To explore the relationship between renewable energy capacity and energy access in Africa, we use data from the International Energy Agency and the Global Solar Atlas project.
Using data from the UN System of Environmental-Economic Accounting, we estimate the economic value of ecosystem services provided by mangrove forests in Southeast Asia.
We examine the impact of microcredit programs on poverty reduction in Asia using household survey data from the Living Standards Measurement Study and credit data from MixMarket.
Using data from the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys and Global Financial Development Database, we investigate the relationship between access to finance and firms' ability to innovate.
This study draws on data from the Living Standards Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture in Ethiopia to assess the relationship between drought exposure and household welfare outcomes.
We construct novel measures of educational infrastructure using primary data from the Annual Status of Education Report (ASER) in India and investigate their impact on learning outcomes.

Considering data from multiple sources including the Food Aid Information System (FAIS), we examine the impact of food aid provision on vulnerable populations with differing levels of nutritional vulnerability.

Using a dataset from the Nigerian Communication Commission and Electricity Distribution Companies, we explore the causal relationship between electricity provision and economic growth at sub-national levels in Nigeria.

We use multiple datasets to investigate the link between trade costs, market entry, and export success: World Bank's Exporter Dynamics Database, World Integrated Trade Solutions NTM database, and the International Logistics Performance Index.
Using high-resolution data from the OpenStreetMap project, we explore how road construction and rehabilitation investments have affected access to healthcare in rural communities.

We analyze data from multiple sources, including the Global Burden of Disease study and World Health Organization database, to understand the burden of non-communicable diseases and examine the associated risk factors at a global level.

This study exploits new security datasets on Nigeria produced by the Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED) to examine patterns of violence and crime and their impact on economic development in sub-national regions of Nigeria.

Using the Poverty and Shared Prosperity Database and the World Development Indicators, we assess the relationship between social protection spending and poverty reduction across countries and over time.

This study uses both the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) data and a complementary dataset on the Fast-Food Restaurant Market to investigate the relationship between fast food consumption and obesity rates in the US.

We examine the impact of international aid on the economic growth of recipient countries using the AidData dataset, which contains information on around 5 million development finance activities from 1947 to 2019, and the World Development Indicators dataset from the World Bank.

To explore the links between air pollution and health outcomes, we use the Global Burden of Disease Study datasets and complement those with long-term air pollution measurement datasets from various sources.

Using the Enterprise Surveys dataset, we analyze how access to finance affects small and medium-sized firms and find that financial constraints create liquidity shortages that slow business activity, especially in low-income countries.

This report examines the role of mining in the economies of African countries by analyzing the dataset compiled by the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), which provides comprehensive information on all payments made by mining and oil companies operating in Africa.

In order to estimate the returns to education across gender and income levels, we use the household datasets from the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) and the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), and investigate how education affects labor market outcomes.

This paper explores the effects of climate change on agricultural yields in sub-Saharan Africa using dataset on daily rainfall, temperature and solar radiation from TerraClimate and crop output data from the Food and Agriculture Organization.
We evaluate the development impact of infrastructure in South Asia by analyzing the AidData dataset and the World Bank's Systematic Tracking of Exchanges in Procurement (STEP) database.
This study uses data from the Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) dataset to examine patterns of urban migration and job polarization in the US labor market over the past two decades.

To investigate the relationship between obesity and socioeconomic status, we use population-based survey data from the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) and supplement these with a dataset on food prices from the Consumer Price Index.
We analyze data on energy consumption from the Global Energy Statistical Yearbook and complement it with satellite imagery to estimate household electrification rates across sub-Saharan Africa.
Using a dataset of over 10,000 households in Uganda from the Living Standards Measurement Study, we examine the relationship between access to financial services and household poverty.

This paper investigates the effects of public-private partnerships on road infrastructure development in Indonesia, using a dataset of PPP projects from the World Bank Private Participation in Infrastructure (PPI) database.

We use a dataset comprised of firm-level data from the manufacturing industry in Mexico and complement it with environmental data from the National Institute of Ecology and Climate Change to examine the effect of pollution abatement regulations on firm productivity.
By combining data from multiple sources including the Global Terrorism Database, we investigate the spatial and temporal dynamics of terrorist attacks in South Asia.

We employ a panel dataset of skilled migration flows from the World Bank Bilateral Migration Matrix and find that migrants' English language proficiency plays a significant role in their choice of destination country.

This study uses household survey data from the Demographic and Health Surveys and satellite imagery data to investigate the impact of climate change on access to safe water sources in sub-Saharan Africa.

We explore the relationship between inequality and electoral participation in Latin America, drawing on a dataset comprised of political participation and social indicators from multiple sources including the Inter-American Development Bank.

Using a time-series dataset on agricultural prices from the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, we examine the effect of market integration on smallholder farmer welfare in rural Kenya.

This paper employs a cross-country panel dataset on renewable energy policies from the International Renewable Energy Agency to compare the effectiveness of various policy instruments in promoting renewable energy uptake across different countries.
The study utilizes data from the Global Hunger Index and Household Consumption Expenditure Data to analyze food insecurity trends in sub-Saharan Africa.
We employed a dataset on carbon emissions from fossil fuel consumption and combustion, along with GDP data to investigate the relationship between economic growth and climate change.
This research uses a dataset of patent filings by firms in the pharmaceutical industry and analyzes how intellectual property rights affect the industry's competitiveness.
By using a panel dataset that includes government debt of various eurozone countries between 2010 and 2021, this paper assesses the impact of sovereign debt on economic growth.
We combine two complementary datasets, social media data and meteorological data, to analyze the effect of extreme weather events on online discussions of climate change.

Using the World Risk Poll and Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery datasets, we examine how disaster risk management measures can improve resilience and reduce risks for people living in developing countries.

We use data on household consumption and expenditure from the Indonesian Family Life Survey (IFLS) to explore the effects of peer interactions on household food consumption behavior.

We employ a novel dataset combining satellite imagery from NASA's MODIS instrument with administrative data on forest concessions in the Peruvian Amazon region to assess the effectiveness of conservation policies aimed at reducing deforestation rates
Our analysis is based on a sample of publicly-traded Chinese manufacturing firms extracted from the China Stock Market & Accounting Research (CSMAR) database and covers the period 2002-2014

We use two datasets: the Global Consumption and Income Project (GCIP), which provides detailed income distribution data, and the World Bank Enterprise Surveys, which contain information on firm characteristics such as business environment constraints and performance indicators.
This study utilizes data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey and the IMF Financial Access Survey to examine the effect of financial inclusion on firm performance.
We analyzed survey data collected from smallholder farmers in four African countries using machine learning techniques to identify key factors contributing to low agricultural productivity.

Using a dataset compiled from various public sources, we estimate the greenhouse gas emissions from the top ten global shipping companies and provide recommendations on how to reduce their carbon footprint.
This article combines household survey data with satellite imagery to investigate the relationship between urbanization, deforestation, and poverty reduction in the Brazilian Amazon.
To examine the impact of infrastructure development on economic growth, we use a comprehensive dataset on infrastructure projects from the World Bank and national statistical offices.
Our analysis uses a longitudinal dataset that tracks the mental health of children in low-income households in rural India over a period of five years.
By integrating multiple large-scale datasets, we investigate how gender inequality affects workforce participation and economic growth in developing countries.
We use a combination of satellite data, GIS maps, and household surveys to analyze the impact of climate change on agricultural production and food security in Ethiopia.
This paper utilizes a unique dataset that combines credit bureau data and transactional banking data to analyze consumer behavior in the mortgage market in South Africa.
Combining household survey data and administrative records, we evaluate the impact of conditional cash transfer programs on reducing poverty and promoting human capital development in Brazil.
This paper analyzes the relationship between agricultural productivity and poverty using a panel dataset from rural Bangladesh.
We combine household survey data with geospatial dataset on land use changes in Brazil over the last decade to examine the effects of deforestation on local communities.
Using a large-scale administrative dataset on medical claims in Mexico, we analyze the impact of a national policy that promotes healthy eating habits among working women.

This study employs two datasets on financial inclusion, one from a survey of households in Uganda and another from a mobile money provider with national coverage, to investigate the determinants of financial literacy.

We estimate the causal effect of climate change on economic growth by combining temperature and precipitation data from the WorldClim dataset with GDP per capita data from WDI for 150 countries over the period 1960-2014.

Using firm-level data from the Enterprise Surveys conducted by the World Bank, we investigate the linkages between female ownership and performance in the extractive industries sector in sub-Saharan Africa.

This paper uses two complementary datasets to study the impact of trade facilitation on export diversification in developing countries: one from the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement Database and another from the UN Comtrade database.
Combining grid-level data on electricity demand with experimental data on household behavior in India, this paper estimates the potential for load shifting using pricing incentives.

To investigate the impact of public-private partnerships (PPP) on transport infrastructure development, we use a panel dataset that tracks PPP projects involving both domestic and foreign investors across 14 countries in Sub-Saharan Africa over the period 2000-2015.

Using data from the World Values Survey and a complementary dataset on school enrollment and attendance in Indonesia, we examine the heterogeneous effects of education on attitudes toward gender equality.
We use two complementary datasets to analyze the effect of climate change on agricultural production, namely the FAO's Agricultural Production Indices and the IPCC's climate models.
This study examines the relationship between financial sector development and income inequality in Nigeria using a combination of World Bank's Enterprise Surveys and Household Longitudinal Surveys.

We apply the random forest algorithm on the digitized data from World Health Organization's reports on Child Malnutrition along with Global Nutrition Report and United Nations' data on conflict to identify the risk factors for child malnutrition in conflict-affected countries.
Using firm-level data on innovation activities from the World Bank's Innovation Survey, we investigate the relationship between adoptability of new technologies and firms' financial performance.

We use the Household Income and Expenditure survey along with the poverty mapping dataset developed by the National Statistics Office to investigate the determinants of urban poverty in the Philippines.

Our analysis uses household survey data from the Demographic and Health Surveys and the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey to identify the factors affecting maternal health outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa.

We analyze the impact of a road infrastructure project on firm's productivity using two complementary datasets: African Development Bank's Road Network dataset and World Bank's Enterprise Survey on Uganda.

This research uses the Global Findex database and the Universal Financial Access dataset along with household survey data to estimate the cost-effectiveness of promoting financial inclusion as a means to reduce poverty and achieve sustainable development goals.

We explore the relationship between air pollution and respiratory illness using satellite data from NASA, ground-based monitoring data from the Chinese Government, and health survey data from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention.
This paper analyses the determinants of electricity consumption patterns in Kenya using monthly data from Kenya Power and Lighting Company and National Bureau of Statistics Household survey data.
The study combines data from the Food Security Information Network and the World Food Program Vulnerability Analysis and Mapping branch in East Africa.

Using data from both the Demographic and Health Surveys and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys conducted in Southeast Asia, we estimate the magnitude and gender-specific distribution of child stunting in the region.
This research uses a unique dataset on firms in Mexico, which includes custom information on international trade activities and the Economic Census data collected every five years.

We combine household survey data collected in partnership with the government and social media data on migration stories to examine the relationship between migration and mental health outcomes in Northern Central America.

This paper analyzes the dynamics of carbon stocks in oil palm plantations using datasets on soil carbon stock changes under different management practices and remote sensing imagery for land cover change detection.

In this study, we use panel data on firms from the World Bank Enterprise Survey and satellite measurements of greenness derived from Landsat imagery to investigate the impact of agglomeration economies on green productivity.

We construct a dataset linking satellite-based measures of economic activity with microdata from household surveys in sub-Saharan Africa to study the relationship between access to electricity and poverty reduction.

This article uses a national dataset on air quality monitoring sites and daily meteorological data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to examine the effectiveness of air pollution policies in improving ambient air quality in the United States.
Using a panel dataset of firms in Ethiopia and survey data that captures informal worker-firm interactions, we evaluate the contribution of informal employment to firm performance and productivity.

In this paper, we use the International Energy Agency's global energy and CO2 emissions database and the World Bank's Global Financial Inclusion Database to investigate the role of financial inclusion in energy access for poor households in developing countries.
Using the latest data from the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys, we examine the relationship between export growth and firm productivity in low-income countries.
This study employs a new dataset on malaria in pregnancy to investigate the impact of climate change on maternal and child health outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa.

We draw on a unique dataset of household surveys that were conducted before and after a massive earthquake in Nepal to investigate the long-term effects of disasters on household consumption and poverty.

This research uses administrative data on Syrian refugee households collected by the United Nations Development Programme to study the impact of cash assistance programs on economic activities and social welfare in Jordan.
Using a rich panel dataset of individual tax returns, we estimate the causal effect of debt relief granted to individuals following bankruptcy on their future labor market outcomes.

This book chapter draws on several complementary datasets, including survey data on children and their caregivers, school infrastructure data, and teacher information collected through classroom observations and self-reports.
We analyze a large, cross-country dataset on women's economic opportunities, which includes indicators such as laws governing work, access to finance, and property rights.
Using satellite data combined with ground-based meteorological information, we estimate the effect of climate variables on yields of major cereal crops in Sub-Saharan Africa.

This paper uses data from nationally representative household surveys that are merged with geospatial information to evaluate the extent to which transport infrastructure investments have reduced spatial income disparities in Mozambique.

We exploit a new dataset that combines information about industrial pollution sources with air quality monitoring data to estimate the causal impact of pollution on school absenteeism and educational outcomes among children in Indonesia.
Using the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys database from 2016, we analyze the relationship between women-owned businesses and access to finance in Latin America and the Caribbean.
We use the Global Consumption Database to examine patterns of meat consumption around the world and their implications for climate change mitigation efforts.
This study combines data from the Fragile States Index and the International Debt Statistics database to explore the impact of debt on fragility and conflict in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Using a combination of satellite data from NASA and meteorological data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), we investigate the relationship between air pollution and extreme weather events.

This paper uses data from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) to estimate the impact of renewable energy policies on jobs and economic growth in developing countries.

We combine household survey data from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) with geospatial data on water availability to measure the impact of water scarcity on public health outcomes in Ethiopia.

We use firm-level data from the World Bank's Doing Business database and a complementary dataset of internet search volumes to investigate the relationship between business regulations and corruption in Asia.

This study draws on panel data from the World Values Survey and the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) to explore the relationship between family planning policies and women's empowerment in sub-Saharan Africa.
We construct a novel dataset that combines satellite imagery from ESA's Sentinel-2 program with administrative data on crop yields to estimate the impact of climate change on food security in India.
Using data from the Human Development Index and the World Inequality Database, we investigate the relationship between education and income inequality across different regions of the world.
This study uses data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and the Global Findex database to assess the role of financial inclusion in firm growth.
Using a panel dataset for 36 European countries over a ten-year period, we examine the impact of regional integration on trade flows.
This report makes use of the EITI database on oil, gas and mining revenues to analyze the impact of transparency on the extractive sector.
We analyze the relationship between access to safe water and poverty through data gathered from the WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene (JMP).
Using the World Values Survey and the Afrobarometer, this study examines the impact of social capital on democratic governance in sub-Saharan Africa.

We use household survey data from the Living Standards Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA) to investigate the impact of climate-smart agriculture practices on food security in Uganda.
This report draws on data from the UNHCR Population Statistics Database and the World Bank's Global Bilateral Migration database to assess the impact of conflict on forced displacement and migration.

We complement satellite-based indicators of deforestation obtained from the Global Forest Watch with data from the Brazilian Agricultural Census to investigate the drivers of land use change in the Brazilian Amazon.
Using household survey data from the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS), we examine the determinants of childhood malnutrition in Haiti.
This study uses data from the World Development Indicators and the Doing Business report to analyze the relationship between infrastructure quality and economic growth.
This study uses data from the Global Findex Database to analyze the relationship between financial inclusion and household welfare in developing countries.
Using data from the LSMS-ISA in Uganda, this paper examines the impact of climate change on household welfare outcomes, including food security and asset ownership.
We utilize a unique dataset combining geospatial and socioeconomic data from a survey conducted in Brazil to assess the spatial distribution of accessibility to various urban services.

This paper draws on a longitudinal dataset of firms in India to examine the determinants of firm performance, taking into account factors such as innovation, export behavior, and managerial characteristics.
We use data from multiple sources - including satellite images and ground-based measurements - to estimate the spatiotemporal variability of soil moisture in the Congo Basin.

Using data from the Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) in multiple African countries, we investigate the link between women's empowerment and child nutrition outcomes, controlling for a variety of demographic and economic factors.

This study explores the use of machine learning techniques to analyze data from a large-scale survey of households in Mexico, with the goal of predicting credit risk and improving financial inclusion.
We use a panel dataset on Chinese prefectures to examine the impact of infrastructure investment on regional economic growth, taking into account spatial spillovers and heterogeneity across regions.

This article uses satellite data on nighttime lights and electrical power outages to estimate the extent of energy access deficits in sub-Saharan Africa, and to identify patterns of both urban and rural electrification.

We draw on data from both the World Values Survey and the European Social Survey to explore the relationship between trust in government and citizen participation in diverse contexts, assessing whether this relationship varies across different social groups.
This report analyzes data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey, specifically focusing on the manufacturing sector in East Asia and the Pacific region.
We combine data from the International Energy Agency's Global EV Outlook and the United Nations Population Division to project future demand for electric vehicles in India.
Using data from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, we analyze the impact of climate change on global fisheries production.
Our analysis combines the World Bank's Poverty and Shared Prosperity dataset with a household survey conducted in rural Ethiopia.
This study uses data from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the World Food Programme to examine food security among refugees living in urban areas.
We rely on data from the International Monetary Fund's Financial Access Survey and the Global Findex database to compare access to financial services across different regions of the world.
To better understand the relationship between financial development and economic growth, we utilize data from the World Bank's Global Financial Development Database and the Penn World Table.
Our analysis draws upon a panel dataset of 60 African countries covering the period 1990-2015, obtained from the Afrobarometer.
Using data from the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund, we examine the impact of improved sanitation facilities on child health outcomes in low-income countries.

In order to assess the impact of public-private partnerships on infrastructure development, we analyze data from the Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility and a cross-country database of PPP projects compiled by the World Bank.
Using data from the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys, we investigate the effects of labor regulations on firm productivity in Latin American and Caribbean countries.
This report analyzes survey data collected by Gallup Pakistan to identify key drivers of employment outcomes for youth in urban areas.

We analyze data from the Nigeria General Household Survey Panel, which combines rich household-, plot-, and community-level information.

Our analysis is based on a global dataset of health systems performance indicators that were measured periodically between 1990 and 2015, along with hand-collected qualitative case studies of health financing reforms from eight low- and middle-income countries.

This paper utilizes two sets of data: individual data from the regular waves of the Household Income and Expenditure Survey (HIES) in Cambodia and enterprise data of formal and informal firms in two provinces.

We use publicly available microdata from Integrated Household Survey conducted by the Tunisian Statistical Office and identify individuals who own firms from the household registry to construct a matched employer-employee dataset.

This analysis uses panel data spanning more than two decades from the Population and Housing Census, farm survey data collected by the Thai government, and satellite images.

We analyze household survey data collected by the Malawi National Statistical Office and data on weather patterns from the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data to understand the impact of climate change on the crop yields and labor supply of smallholder farmers.

This paper investigates the effect of financial inclusion initiatives on poverty reduction by using a panel dataset comprising of World Bank's Global Findex and household surveys from developing countries.

This study utilizes the Global Health Data Exchange's malaria prevalence data and WorldPop's population distribution maps to identify regions with high vulnerability to malaria in Sub-Saharan Africa.

This report utilizes data from the Global Findex and the World Bank Enterprise Surveys to analyze patterns of financial inclusion among women entrepreneurs in Sub-Saharan Africa.

We analyze a unique, georeferenced dataset on transport infrastructure quality from the Afrobarometer surveys, which measure African citizens' attitudes towards democracy, governance, economic conditions and related issues in over 30 countries in sub-Saharan Africa.

Using the Renewable Energy Policy Network for the 21st Century's (REN21) Renewables Global Status Report and the World Inequality Database on Energy (WIDE), we explore the relationship between renewable energy production and reducing global income inequality.

Using data from the World Values Survey (WVS) and the European Social Survey(ESS), we investigate how trust in social institutions, such as the government, media, and education, varies across countries and regions and its socio-economic consequences on regional integration.
Using data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey and Global Financial Development Database, we analyze the impact of financial constraints on firm performance in low-income countries.

We combine high-resolution land cover maps with climate, soil, and conservation data to assess the potential for community-based forest management as a strategy for biodiversity conservation in the tropics.
Employing two complementary data sources, namely administrative records and survey data, we analyze the relationship between public transport connectivity and unemployment in urban areas of Europe.
This paper examines the links between air pollution and cardiovascular disease using data from both a national health survey dataset and an air quality monitoring dataset, both from China.
We use a unique dataset on informal traders in Accra, Ghana that combines geospatial mapping and survey data to analyze factors affecting their choice of location and daily earnings.

Using household survey data from the World Bank Living Standard Measurement Study, we examine the determinants of child nutrition outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa.

This paper analyzes changes in financial inclusion by utilizing data from a nationally representative survey in India, the All-India Debt and Investment Survey (AIDIS).

To better understand how energy security can be improved, we analyze three complementary datasets: Global Energy Statistical Yearbook, BP Statistical Review of World Energy, and International Energy Agency databases.
We use data on institutional quality, trade openness and economic growth from 87 countries over the period 1985-2016 to assess the effects of institutional factors on trade performance.
This research paper employs a novel dataset of firm-level household donations in Tanzania to investigate whether corporate social responsibility activities enhance firm performance.

In order to evaluate the effectiveness of public-private partnerships in China's transport sector, we compile data from various sources, including surveys of private investors by the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and China's Ministry of Transport database.

This paper uses a panel dataset of firms in the extractive industries sector in Africa to examine the role of institutional quality and firm size on environmental performance.

Using household survey data from the Mexican Family Life Survey and geographic information system data on vegetation coverage, we assess the impact of deforestation on household welfare in rural Mexico.

Our study combines two rich datasets: the nationally representative household-level Ghana Living Standards Survey (GLSS) from 2016-17, and an administrative dataset from the Ghana Education Service (GES).

This analysis uses high-resolution rainfall data from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and Conflict and Health dataset assembled by the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project (ACLED).

We analyzed data from multiple sources such as the Demographic and Health Survey, the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, the Global School-based Student Health Survey and other data to assess gender differences in tobacco use across different countries.

Using geospatial data, specifically Landsat 8 imagery and Open Street Maps (OSM), we estimate the impacts of urban unplanned settlements on water access for different population groups

Using Migrant Stock Database generated by the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs, we analyze the long-term effects of migration on regional productivity growth in developed countries.

By using rich administrative data from the Informal Economic Survey collected by the Mexico National Institute of Statistics and Geography, we investigate various aspects of informality and their determinants.

This study analyzes the effectiveness of government-funded energy efficiency programs in China's manufacturing industry using firm-level data from the Annual Survey of Industrial Enterprises and energy consumption data from the China Industrial Energy Audit Database.

Using data from the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys and a regional dataset on foreign-owned firms, we examined the impact of competition on firm performance in East Africa.

In order to explore the relationship between debt and economic growth in Latin America, we used a panel dataset that combines information from public sources such as the IMF, World Bank, and Central Banks of the region.
This study analyzed survey data collected from households in Kenya, Uganda, and Tanzania to assess the impact of mobile money services on household financial behavior and access to finance.

To better understand factors influencing air pollution levels in urban centers, we combined satellite data from NASA's Aura mission with ground-based sensor data from the Beijing Municipal Environmental Monitoring Center.

Using data from the Global Terrorism Database and news articles from around the world, we conducted an analysis of the relationship between media coverage of terrorist incidents and subsequent patterns of violent extremism.
We used a nationally representative dataset of students in the United States to explore the relationship between school climate and academic achievement.
This paper examines the effectiveness of public-private partnerships in infrastructure development through an analysis of data from the World Bank's Private Participation in Infrastructure Database.

We employed a multinomial logit model to investigate the determinants of mode choice for commuting in urban areas using data from the Transportation Analysis and Simulation System (TRANSIMS) and the National Personal Transportation Survey.
This study assessed the impact of a nutrition education program on childhood malnutrition rates in rural Malawi using data collected from a randomized controlled trial conducted in 2014-2016.

Agriculture continues to be an important sector for economic growth and poverty reduction, and this study uses data from the World Bank's Living Standard Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA) to examine the relationship between agricultural intensification and household welfare in Mozambique.
This research analyzes the impact of climate change on droughts by using a gridded dataset of precipitation and temperature.
The study employs a comprehensive dataset which covers 35 countries and provides detailed information on macroeconomic indicators such as productivity, prices, investments, and trade.
This paper examines how natural resource wealth and governance affect public debt sustainability using a panel dataset covering 55 resource-rich countries.
Drawing on transaction-level data from the Central Bank of Nigeria and secondary data sources, we explore the effect of mobile money services on financial inclusion in rural areas of Nigeria.

To measure the impact of extractive industries on local communities, we employ two unique datasets: one containing detailed information on mining concessions, and another containing household-level survey data.

This research examines how different dimensions of governance contribute to economic diversification in Sub-Saharan Africa and employs data from the World Bank's Worldwide Governance Indicators and the United Nations' Comtrade database.
Using household survey data and remotely sensed data, this paper investigates the relationship between deforestation and food security in Brazil’s Legal Amazon.
This project explores whether cash transfers can alleviate poverty in developing countries by analyzing data from randomized controlled trials conducted in seven African countries.
We use a combination of satellite-based fire detection data and land cover maps to examine the drivers of forest fires in Indonesia over the past two decades.

Using data from the World Bank Enterprise Surveys and the Global Financial Inclusion (Global Findex) Database, we examine the relationship between financial inclusion and firm performance in low- and middle-income countries.
Our study draws on data from the DHS conducted in Sub-Saharan African countries with at least two rounds of data to explore the determinants of child mortality in the region.
We employ high-frequency loan-level data from a commercial bank operating in Uzbekistan to identify causes and consequences of customer delinquency.
This paper analyzes the impacts of climate change on crop yields using data from the Integrated Assessment Modeling framework.

We use two main sources of data - the Social Welfare Development Indicator System (SWDIS) and the Overseas Korean Foundation for Children and Families record system - to identify the most vulnerable populations during the COVID-19 pandemic in South Korea.
The study uses panel data on Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita and internet usage across multiple countries over a span of several years.
