This paper examines the role of gender in shaping the impact of trade liberalization using firm-level customs transaction data merged with household survey data.

We combine geospatial information with a wealth of household survey data collected in seven African countries under the Living Standards Measurement Study/Integrated Surveys on Agriculture, allowing us to identify communities prone to food insecurity hence vulnerable to climate change and other environmental shocks.

This study uses household-level data from multiple rounds of the Living Standards Measurement Study to examine the relationship between disability status and measures of economic well-being in low- and middle-income countries.

We use a unique dataset covering all international air passengers who entered or exited South Korea to identify some factors that may affect the decision to travel by air during the COVID-19 pandemic.

We merge detailed trade data from firm-level exporters across three East African countries with newly available transportation costs by postal code and find significant heterogeneity in the extensive margin response to changes in transportation costs across firms and export destinations within and across countries.
We use fine-grained geolocation information for over 10,000 public schools in Uganda linked to administrative data on teacher attendance, school resources and performance.
This study combines data from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Diabetes Federation to estimate prevalence and incidence of diabetes globally.
To examine the relationship between climate change and food security, we use two complementary datasets: the Global Food Security Index and the Climate Vulnerability Index.
We analyze a unique dataset of cross-border bank lending to 129 countries over the period 1995-2015, provided by the Bank for International Settlements.
Our analysis is based on household-level data from the Demographic and Health Surveys conducted in Ghana and Mali.
To explore the socioeconomic determinants of COVID-19 mortality, we use data from the World Health Organization and the World Bank's World Development Indicators.
We draw on multiple sources of data, including satellite images, district-level census data, and reports from the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council.

We use an innovative methodological approach that combines data from GLOBOCAN with publicly available subnational cancer registry data to produce estimates for states in Mexico that lack reliable cancer incidence data.
We analyze data from the Indonesian Family Life Survey, a longitudinal survey of a nationally representative sample of households.
This study uses data on firm-level productive spending patterns from Cote d'Ivoire and Nigeria to examine the effects of regional integration on firms' competitiveness.
We use household survey data from seven countries in sub-Saharan Africa to investigate the extent of energy poverty and its relation to health outcomes and education.
To analyze the impact of extractive industries on economic growth, we use dataset collected from World Development Indicators and the Extractives Industry Transparency Initiative (EITI)
This study investigates the relationship between job training and wages using data from National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) and Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS)

To estimate the impacts of rural electrification programs on agricultural productivity, we utilize data from Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Living Standards Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA)
We explore the effects of early childhood nutrition on cognitive development by utilizing data from Bangladesh Integrated Household Survey (BIHS) and Young Lives
This paper analyzes the gender wage gap across different sectors in Indonesia using data from Labor Force Survey (SAKERNAS) and Indonesia Family Life Survey (IFLS)
To investigate the effect of infrastructure investments on economic growth, we combine data from the International Road Federation (IRF) and World Development Indicators

We use multiple datasets, including National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and European Space Agency (ESA), to study the impact of climate change on food security in Sub-Saharan Africa
This study examines the relationship between financial inclusion and economic growth using data from Global Findex and World Development Indicators

We investigate the effectiveness of public-private partnerships in infrastructure development by analyzing data from Public-Private Infrastructure Advisory Facility (PPIAF) and World Bank's Private Participation in Infrastructure Database (PPI Database)
To study the impact of water scarcity on agricultural productivity, we utilize data from Future Water project and Living Standards Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA)
This study uses data from the World Bank Enterprise Survey and the Global Findex to examine the relationship between financial inclusion and firm performance in low-income countries.

We leverage panel data from the Living Standards Measurement Study-Integrated Surveys on Agriculture (LSMS-ISA) and Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) to investigate the impact of agricultural practices on child nutrition outcomes in Mali.
Using data collected from the World Bank's Logistics Performance Index (LPI), we examine the impact of logistics performance on economic competitiveness across 185 countries.
We combine household survey data with satellite imagery from the Sentinel-2 mission to estimate the impact of drought on crop yields and household welfare in rural Uganda.
This paper analyzes the causal effect of public debt on economic growth using data from the IMF's Government Finance Statistics and World Economic Outlook databases for a global sample of countries.

We use a dataset of bank-level indicators from the World Bank's Global Financial Development Database to investigate the effects of digital financial services on financial sector stability in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Drawing on datasets from the World Bank's Macro Poverty Outlook and Universal Health Coverage Global Monitoring Report, we discuss the challenges of achieving universal health coverage in low-income countries.
We use a dataset of conflict events collected by the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project (ACLED) to analyze the relationship between education and violence in sub-Saharan Africa.
This study combines data from the World Bank's Enterprise Surveys and Doing Business reports to investigate the impact of electricity access on business performance in developing countries.

Using data from the World Bank's Doing Business surveys and Women, Business and the Law reports, we explore the relationship between gender-based legal restrictions and women's participation in the labor market in Middle East and North African countries.
